thread.title: Watch a Rising Star vocal competition seeks high school seniors | www.palmbeachpost.com
thread.title_full: Watch a Rising Star vocal competition seeks high school seniors | www.palmbeachpost.com

author: Sy O'Neill
title: Watch a Rising Star vocal competition seeks high school seniors | www.palmbeachpost.com
text:
PALM BEACH COUNTY SCHOOLS
JUPITER HIGH
Members of The Pine School s uKnight Capital Campaign Committee mingle with school personnel at a recent event hosted at the Rybovich Marina in West Palm Beach. Celebrating the kickoff of the final phase of the campaign are (from left) Director of Development Kelly Hilton-Green; Don Mader; Keenan Siegel; Head of School Phyllis Parker; Ramsey Small; Amy Branden; and Debbie Textor. The campaign, which has already exceeded 50 percent of its goal, has been bolstered by an anonymous $1 million gift and a $500,000 matching gift. The Homecoming Parade starts at 4 p.m. Oct. 8, and the carnival follows at 6. The Homecoming football game is at 7 p.m. Oct. 9.
The Homecoming dance begins at 8 p.m. Oct. 10 in the gymnasium. Tickets are on sale in front of the gymnasium ticket booth during lunch hour. Tickets purchased through Friday are $20, with the price increasing to $25 the following week. No tickets will be sold at the door.
The school will host its inaugural College Fair 6 to 8 p.m. Oct. 14. For more information, contact Cindy Ferrara, college adviser, or Suzie Tamoney, event coordinator at jupiterhighcollegefair@gmail.com.
BRIEFLY
West Palm Beach Macaroni Kid will host a school showcase 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Oct. 14 at Downtown at the Gardens. More than 30 local preschools, private schools and charter schools will participate, providing information on open house events and registration.
Middle school students in the district are invited to participate in the free Cell Phone Film Festival presented by G-Star Studios. The staff of G-Star School will teach students how to write, film and edit their own short films at an orientation session from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Oct. 17. Details and a schedule of activities are available at www.gstarschool.org/cpff
Junior Achievement of the Palm Beaches & Treasure Coast is sponsoring its 14th annual Watch a Rising Star competition. Area high school seniors can perform in the vocal competition for a chance to win $10,000 in scholarship prizes. Nominations to audition are due Friday. Open auditions take place at 10 a.m. Oct. 17 at Palm Beach Atlantic University. To receive a short nomination form, email Nathalie Glaze at nglaze@juniorachievement.com or call 561-242-9468, ext. 203. A pool of five finalists will be selected from the auditions to compete Feb. 13 at The Kravis Center for the Performing Arts.
Superintendent Robert M. Avossa will meet with members of the Guatemalan/Maya community 9 to 11 a.m. Oct. 15 at El Sol Neighborhood Resource Center, 106 Military Trail, Jupiter. The meeting will be conducted in Spanish, except for introductions by School Board members and the presentation by the superintendent. The Multicultural Education Department team and community members will interpret for those who speak Q’anob’al or Mam, as well as for those who speak English. Interpretation headsets will be available.
TREASURE COAST SCHOOLS
Several schools and programs in the Martin County School District are in need of assistance: Indiantown Middle, Riverbend Academy, Willoughby Learning Center (formerly the Challenger School), Spectrum Junior/Senior High, Hobe Sound Elementary, Murray Middle and Warfield Elementary. Visit www.GetOnTheBusMartin.org to learn how you can help.
The Education Foundation of Martin County is asking for the community’s help in naming the Martin County Teacher of the Year. Candidates, who were selected by their peers, are: Kari Cumming, Bessey Creek Elementary; Harvey Cupaiuoli, Willoughby Learning Center; Patricia (Tricia) Martin, Citrus Grove Elementary; Katie Michalowski, Crystal Lake Elementary; Melissa DuBois, Dr. David L. Anderson Middle; Eileen Torounian, Felix A. Williams Elementary; Julie Anne Carreiro, Hidden Oaks Middle; Michelle McCree, Hobe Sound Elementary; Siddhi Gullickson, Indiantown Middle; Jonathan Tolliver, J.D. Parker School of Science, Math & Technology; Adele Catapano, Jensen Beach Elementary; Ellie Thompson, Jensen Beach High; Jamie Herd-Tesson, Martin County High; Patricia Lawson, Murray Middle; Alissa McGraw, Palm City Elementary; Hillary Schommer, Pinewood Elementary; Melissa Fischer-Rasmussen, Port Salerno Elementary; Allison Gribbin, Riverbend Academy; Stephanie Ressler, SeaWind Elementary; Timothy (Sam) Elliott, South Fork High; Alec McIntyre, Stuart Middle; and Alexis Rooney, Warfield Elementary. The name of the winning teachers will be revealed during the Education Foundation of Martin County’s Teacher of the Year Awards Celebration on Nov. 13. Vote at www.audistuart.com .
Compiled by Sy O’Neill. Send school news to neighborhood@pbpost.com. Dated items must be sent at least two weeks before the event.</p
